questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of nausea, headache, and generalized fatigue for 2 days. He has not vomited. He was diagnosed with small cell lung cancer and liver metastases around 3 months ago and is currently receiving chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide. His last chemotherapy cycle ended one week ago. He has chronic obstructive lung disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and a salmeterol-fluticasone inhaler. He appears malnourished. He is oriented to time, place, and person. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg. There is no edema. Examination shows decreased breath sounds over the left lung. Cardiac examination shows an S4. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4300/mm3



Platelet count
146,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

125 mEq/L


 Cl−

105 mEq/L


 K+

4.5 mEq/L


 HCO3−

24 mEq/L


 Glucose
225 mg/dL


 Total bilirubin
1.1 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase
110 U/L


 AST
78 U/L


 ALT
90 U/L


Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following set of laboratory findings?



Serum osmolality
Urine osmolality
Urinary sodium excretion



A
220 mOsm/kg H2O
130 mOsm/kg H2O
10 mEq/L


B
269 mOsm/kg H2O
369 mOsm/kg H2O
82 mEq/L


C
255 mOsm/kg H2O
45 mOsm/kg H2O
12 mEq/L


D
222 mOsm/kg H2O
490 mOsm/kg H2O
10 mEq/L


E
310 mOsm/kg H2O
420 mOsm/kg H2O
16 mEq/L
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This is the expected laboratory finding in patients with hypervolemic hyponatremia (e.g., due to cirrhosis or congestive heart failure). Despite hypervolemia, effective circulating volume is diminished (from low cardiac output in congestive heart failure or splanchnic vasodilation in cirrhosis), causing the kidneys to incorrectly detect a state of hypovolemia. Subsequent activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and secretion of antidiuretic hormone leads to a net effect of reabsorption of a greater amount of free water than sodium, resulting in hyponatremia. Although this patient does have signs of liver damage (likely from metastasis and cisplatin therapy), these do not suggest cirrhosis (only mildly elevated liver enzymes, absence of ascites).

B) CORRECT:

SIADH will result in free water reabsorption in the kidneys by increasing aquaporins in the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts. Excess free water retention causes low serum osmolality (< 280 mOsm/kg) and hyponatremia (< 135 mEq/L), as well as concentrated urine (> 100 mOsm/kg). Since the patient is euvolemic and therefore does not retain sodium through activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, there will be normal to high urine sodium excretion (> 20–30 mEq/L).
Image Description:

FENa: fractional excretion of sodium
SIADH: syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
TURP: transurethral resection of the prostate
UNa: urine sodium
UOsm: urine osmolality

C) INCORRECT:

These would be the expected laboratory results in primary polydipsia. An excess in free water intake will lower serum osmolality and cause a compensatory reduction in the secretion of antidiuretic hormone, which will dilute urine to a maximum (reducing urine osmolality) to excrete excess fluid. Urine sodium excretion will remain low, however, as the kidneys will respond to reduced serum osmolality by reabsorbing sodium. This patient does not have a history of drinking excessive amounts of fluid, making these findings unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

These would be the expected laboratory findings in patients with extrarenal fluid loss (e.g., vomiting, diarrhea), indicating hypovolemic hyponatremia. Loss of sodium and free water will decrease effective circulating volume and cause secretion of antidiuretic hormone and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Therefore, urinary sodium excretion is decreased and osmolality is elevated as the kidneys work to reabsorb free water and sodium from the urine. The net effect is retention of more free water than sodium, resulting in hyponatremia. As the patient has not had any vomiting or diarrhea, this diagnosis is unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

These would be the expected laboratory results in hypertonic hyponatremia (e.g., due to hyperglycemia). In hyperglycemia, excess glucose will increase the serum osmolality and cause hyponatremia through water shift (osmosis) from the intracellular to the extracellular space (serum sodium levels decrease by 1.6 points for each 100 mg/dL glucose above normal). The actual sodium content does not change. Glucose excreted in the urine will cause elevated urine osmolality and urine sodium excretion will be low due to likely hypovolemia from osmotic diuresis and subsequent activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Although this patient does have elevated glucose levels (225 mg/dL), this does not account for the degree of his hyponatremia.
questions.hint: Small cell lung cancer is commonly associated with paraneoplastic syndromes such as syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). Nausea, headache, and fatigue in this patient are likely due to the hyponatremia caused by this paraneoplastic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and irregular menstrual cycles for the past year. She also complains of recurrent sinus infections. During the past 6 months, she has had increased urinary frequency and swelling of her feet. She has also had difficulty lifting her 3-year-old niece for the past 3 weeks. She was recently diagnosed with depression. She works as a medical assistant. The patient has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years and drinks four beers on the weekends. Her only medication is escitalopram. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (175 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. She appears tired. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows excess fat around the base of the neck and an enlarged abdomen. Examination of the skin shows multiple bruises on her arms and legs. There is generalized weakness and atrophy of the proximal muscles. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



Na+

150 mEq/L


K+

3.0 mEq/L


Cl-

103 mEq/L


HCO3-

30 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
19 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


Glucose
136 mg/dL


A 1 mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test shows a serum cortisol of 167 nmol/L (N < 50) and a 24-hour urinary cortisol is 425 μg (N < 300 μg). Serum ACTH is 169 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Subsequently, a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows a serum cortisol level of 164 nmol/L (N < 50). Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exogenous corticosteroid administration causes negative feedback on ACTH production in the pituitary gland, causing low ACTH levels and presenting as ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. This patient has elevated ACTH levels (ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome) instead, which means the primary cause of her symptoms is ACTH production by either her pituitary gland or an ectopic focus.

B) INCORRECT:

A corticotropic pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease) would result in secondary hypercortisolism due to increased ACTH production by the tumor. However, ACTH production by corticotropic pituitary adenomas is responsive to suppressive feedback by high doses of dexamethasone, and cortisol levels would decrease. Elevated cortisol levels in this patient following a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test suggest a different cause for secondary hypercortisolism.

C) INCORRECT:

Excess cortisol production by an adrenal carcinoma would suppress pituitary secretion of ACTH, leading to low ACTH levels and ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. This patient has elevated ACTH levels, meaning she has ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome from either a pituitary or ectopic source.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can manifest with fatigue, irregular menstrual cycles, weight gain, depression, and lower extremity swelling but we already know from her cortisol level and laboratory studies that she has Cushing syndrome which better explains these symptoms. Hypothyroidism does not cause ectopic ACTH production so this is not the underlying cause of her symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytomas may very rarely manifest with ectopic ACTH production. However, this patient does not have any of the classic symptoms of pheochromocytoma such as paroxysmal elevations in heart rate and blood pressure with palpitations or diaphoresis.

F) CORRECT:

Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is the most common cause of endogenous hypercortisolism from an ectopic source of ACTH. A history of smoking is the strongest risk factor for SCLC. Because SCLC is a pulmonary neuroendocrine tumor, it can produce hormones that are associated with paraneoplastic syndromes including Cushing syndrome, SIADH, and Lambert-Eaton syndrome. In Cushing syndrome due to SCLC, the affected cells produce ACTH, which is not suppressed by high cortisol and is resistant to negative feedback. Consequently, serum cortisol levels remain elevated following a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test, as seen in this patient.

Other cancers which are less commonly associated with the secretion of ACTH or ACTH-like substances include renal cell cancer, bronchial and pancreatic carcinoid tumors, and medullary thyroid carcinomas.

G) INCORRECT:

Excess cortisol production by an adrenal adenoma would suppress pituitary secretion of ACTH, leading to low ACTH levels and ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. This patient has elevated ACTH levels, meaning she has ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome from either a pituitary or ectopic source.
questions.hint: In a patient who is not on glucocorticoid therapy, serum cortisol levels that remain elevated following a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test are consistent with endogenous hypercortisolism. Elevated serum ACTH levels suggest secondary hypercortisolism, while elevated serum cortisol levels following a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test indicate ectopic ACTH production.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of difficulty walking for the last 6 months. He reports weakness in his lower legs that improves with exercise and throughout the day. Three months ago, he started adding flax seeds to his breakfast because he is frequently constipated. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the last 45 years. His current medications include enalapril and metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. Muscle strength in the lower extremities is decreased. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Active muscle contraction or repeated muscle tapping increases reflex activity. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Demyelinating plaques on a brain MRI
Decremental response following repetitive nerve stimulation
Fasciculations and positive sharp waves on EMG

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Demyelinating plaques on a brain MRI are seen in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS), who may present with bilateral lower limb weakness, gait impairment, and/or autonomic dysfunction. However, motor deficits in MS are due to lesions in the descending motor tracts of the spinal cord and therefore the tendon reflexes are usually exaggerated, not diminished.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)

Extensive bilateral demyelinating lesions (plaques) appear as hyperintensities in the periventricular white matter (green overlay). Radial extensions of these lesions (Dawson fingers) are visible. Generalized cerebral atrophy, part of the disease process for multiple sclerosis, is also visible.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with LEMS have autoantibodies against the P/Q voltage-gated calcium channels at the presynaptic motor neuron. In patients with LEMS, the levels of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction are decreased because the autoantibodies impair the release of acetylcholine from the presynaptic terminal of the motor endplate. This results in reduced neuromuscular transmission and muscle weakness. Repetitive nerve stimulation during exercise or during nerve conduction studies increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft, which improves muscle strength and the amplitude of muscle action potentials (since the postsynaptic ACh receptors remain intact).

About two-thirds of all cases of LEMS are associated with an underlying malignancy, most commonly small-cell lung cancer. Given this association and the patient's 90-pack year smoking history, it is imperative that he undergoes a chest X-ray and/or CT.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

C) INCORRECT:

Endomysial infiltrate on muscle biopsy is seen in inclusion body myositis (IBM), which typically occurs in men over 50 years of age and manifests with lower limb weakness that increases progressively over the course of years. This patient presents with a 6-month history of waxing-and-waning muscle weakness that improves with exercise. Also, patients with IBM often present with weakness in the hand or fingers. Also, IBM would not account for this patient's symptoms of autonomic dysfunction (dry mouth, constipation) or reduced deep tendon reflexes.

D) INCORRECT:

A decrement in the muscle action potential following repetitive nerve stimulation is seen in patients with myasthenia gravis (MG). Although MG may manifest with lower limb weakness, other characteristic features such as ptosis and/or diplopia would also be expected. Also, patients with MG have normal deep tendon reflexes despite limb weakness, and autonomic dysfunction would not occur. This patient has Lambert-Eaton syndrome, in which an incremental response follows repetitive nerve stimulation.
Image Description:

(1) Physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end-plate: synaptic vesicles filled with Acetylcholine (ACh) fuse with the presynaptic membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh to the nicotinic ACh receptors (AChR) → opening of receptor ion channel → influx of ions → depolarization, action potential, and contraction of the muscle → breakdown of ACh by cholinesterase and re-uptake in the motor end-plate.

(2) Impaired neuromuscular transmission in Myasthenia gravis: Antibodies compete with ACh for postsynaptic AChRs → ACh cannot bind → receptor ion channel does not open → no neuromuscular transmission

(3) Edrophonium test: Administration of edrophonium (cholinesterase inhibitor) → increase of ACh concentration in the synaptic cleft → increased binding of ACh to AChR → improved neuromuscular transmission.

E) INCORRECT:

Fasciculations and positive sharp waves on EMG would be seen in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). ALS also manifests with weakness and may occasionally be associated with dysautonomia. However, ALS would not account for muscle weakness that improves with exercise or increased reflex activity following active muscle contraction. Additionally, ALS causes progressive rather than episodic weakness.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

F) INCORRECT:

Albuminocytologic dissociation in the cerebral fluid is seen in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) and Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), both of which may manifest with progressive bilateral lower limb weakness, difficulty walking, and hyporeflexia. CSF findings may support these diagnoses, but they are not confirmatory (EMG or nerve conduction is required for confirmation). Moreover, while GBS may manifest with symptoms of autonomic dysfunction, this condition usually resolves within 2 months, making GBS unlikely in this patient whose symptoms have been present for the past 6 months. CIDP may persist for months but is not associated with dysautonomia or improvement of weakness following exercise.
questions.hint: This patient presents with weakness of the lower legs that improves throughout the day and with exercise, in addition to autonomic dysfunction (dry mouth, constipation) and reduced reflexes. These features together with a positive smoking history suggest Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS).

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of a cough for the past 3 months. The cough is mostly dry, but the patient recalls a recent episode in which he coughed up mucus with dark red streaks. He has felt tired for the past few months. Over the past month, he has had poor appetite and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. He also has occasional back pain, which has worsened in recent weeks. He has no recent travel history. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He does not drink alcohol. His vitals are within normal limits. Auscultation of the lungs reveals wheezing in the lower right lung field. There is no peripheral lymphadenopathy. The liver is of normal size, and the spleen is not palpable. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.5 g/dL, serum calcium concentration of 12.3 mg/dL, and a total serum protein of 7.0 g/dL. X-rays of the chest are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma can also manifest with constitutional symptoms (weight loss, pain, fatigue) and hypercalcemia. In particular, this patient's worsening back pain is concerning for spinal involvement. However, pulmonary symptoms and the x-ray findings are not consistent with this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis can cause a productive cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, and bone pain and may manifest with a cavitary lesion on x-ray. However, tuberculous cavities typically form in the superior lobes, and this patient has no additional findings of tuberculosis, such as a calcified granuloma (Ghon complex) or hilar lymphadenopathy. Additionally, this patient does not have signs of infection, such as fever, and has no history of immunocompromise or tuberculosis exposure.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

C) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia may also manifest with wheezing on auscultation and extensive opacity restricted to one pulmonary lobe on x-ray. However, cavitary lesions are unlikely findings in pneumonia, and this patient lacks signs of acute infection, such as fever.

D) INCORRECT:

A productive cough, bloody sputum, and weight loss in an elderly patient with a long history of smoking should raise suspicion for lung cancer. Small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) is strongly associated with smoking and typically causes a centrally located lesion; however, it does not usually form cavitary lesions. While SCLC can cause several paraneoplastic syndromes, hypercalcemia is not typically seen in this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Sarcoidosis can manifest with pulmonary symptoms, constitutional symptoms (weight loss, pain, fatigue), and hypercalcemia. However, the cough in sarcoidosis is typically nonproductive, and x-rays usually show hilar lymphadenopathy with or without bilateral reticular opacities rather than cavitary lesions. Moreover, extrapulmonary manifestations such as peripheral lymphadenopathy or eye or skin lesions are commonly seen in this condition.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient with sarcoidosis

The pulmonary hila (green overlay) are enlarged and lobulated. Additionally, the right superior mediastinum (red overlay) is widened and dense. A normal thin right paratracheal stripe is not seen.

Relatively symmetric bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph node enlargement on a chest radiograph in sarcoidosis is termed the “1-2-3 sign” or “Garland triad.” Examples of other causes of hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy include lymphoma, metastatic disease, granulomatous infections, and inorganic dust disease.

F) CORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung is the most common type of lung cancer in individuals who smoke. SCC can cause centrally located cavitary lesions, which are consistent with this patient's x-ray findings. Certain paraneoplastic syndromes, such as hypercalcemia, primarily arise in association with SCC. Tumor cells in SCC can produce parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP), which stimulates PTH receptors. This stimulation increases bone resorption, renal calcium reabsorption, and decreases calcium excretion, resulting in hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia.
questions.hint: X-rays show a heterogeneous, irregularly demarcated lesion with a central cavity and air-fluid level in the right middle lobe. Which respiratory pathology can also cause hypercalcemia?

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of worsening muscle weakness in her legs and shoulders, which is especially prominent when she stands up or combs her hair. She also reports that she has recently developed a facial rash and episodes in which her fingers become pale and painful. The patient has not been evaluated by a physician in 5 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. She does not drink alcoholic beverages. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows facial erythema and swelling of the upper eyelids. A photograph of her right hand is shown. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the iliopsoas, hamstring, deltoid, and biceps muscles; there is tenderness to palpation in the affected muscle groups. Sensation to pinprick, temperature, and vibration is intact. Laboratory studies show markedly elevated creatine kinase. An electromyogram shows low-amplitude, short-duration, polyphasic action potentials and positive sharp waves. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid antibody assay is indicated in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) to screen for associated antiphospholipid syndrome. SLE typically affects women and manifests with facial erythema (malar rash), muscle weakness, and Raynaud phenomenon. However, this patient presents with heliotrope rash, Gottron papules, elevated creatine kinase, and an irritable myopathic pattern on electromyography, which are not associated with SLE. Additionally, this patient does not have other characteristic features of SLE, such as constitutional symptoms, arthritis, and photosensitivity.

B) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography is used to screen for cardiac complications of systemic sclerosis (Ssc) such as pulmonary hypertension, ventricular dysfunction, and pericardial disease. Symptoms of SSc include muscle weakness, myalgia, Raynaud phenomenon, and skin manifestations on the hands. However, skin manifestations in SSc are characterized by thickening and hardening of the skin, sclerodactyly, and ulcers with atrophy and necrotic spots rather than erythematous, slightly scaly papules. In addition, Ssc is not associated with elevated muscle enzymes and changes on electromyography. Although dermatomyositis can affect the heart, echocardiography is not indicated unless there are symptoms consistent with cardiac involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

An edrophonium test can be used to diagnose myasthenia gravis (MG), which causes proximal limb weakness. However, an electromyogram in MG shows a decremental response to repetitive nerve stimulation, in contrast to the irritable myopathic pattern seen in this patient. MG is not associated with elevated creatine kinase or skin lesions. In addition, this patient does not have other characteristic symptoms of MG, such as impaired vision, slurred speech, and muscle weakness that worsens during the day.

D) INCORRECT:

Temporal artery biopsy is used in the workup of suspected giant cell arteritis (GCA), which is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR), a condition that can manifest with symmetrical weakness of the shoulders and pelvic girdle muscles. However, individuals with PMR typically present with acute onset of pain and stiffness in the affected muscles before developing weakness. PMR is not associated with skin lesions and abnormalities on electromyogram. Additionally, creatine kinase levels in PMR are normal.

E) CORRECT:

Dermatomyositis is associated with an increased risk of malignancies, especially adenocarcinomas of the ovaries, cervix, lung, stomach, pancreas, and colorectum. Therefore, all patients with dermatomyositis should receive standard age-appropriate cancer screening, including breast, pelvic, and prostate exams, mammography, and colonoscopy.

Additionally, all patients should undergo chest x-ray and pulmonary function testing to assess for interstitial lung disease.
questions.hint: This patient presents with certain cutaneous features (heliotrope rash, Gottron papules, Raynaud phenomenon), symmetrical proximal muscle weakness, elevated creatine kinase, and EMG findings that suggest an irritable myopathic pattern, all of which is consistent with dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of behavior changes and involuntary limb movements over the past 2 days. She also has a 2-week history of fever, headache, and fatigue. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 102/72 mm Hg. Mental status examination shows impaired speech and a disorganized thought process. Muscle strength is 5/5 in all extremities. Urine toxicology screening is negative. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 70 cells/mm3 (90% lymphocytes) and a protein concentration of 51 mg/dL. Abdominal ultrasound shows a large right adnexal mass. The patient's symptoms are most likely caused by antibodies against which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoantibodies against the Yo antigens of cerebellar Purkinje cells are seen in paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (PCD) due to gynecological malignancies such as ovarian cancer (adnexal mass). Cerebellar degeneration can result in impaired speech due to dysarthria. However, cerebellar degeneration would not cause features of cognitive defects (e.g., personality change) or autonomic instability (e.g., tachycardia, hypotension), and patients with cerebellar degeneration would have loss of coordination (intention tremor, dysdiadochokinesia, ataxia) and nystagmus rather than involuntary limb movements.

B) INCORRECT:

GM1 ganglioside autoantibodies are involved in the pathogenesis of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), which is often preceded by symptoms of a viral infection (e.g., fever, headache, fatigue) and can manifest with features of autonomic instability (e.g., tachycardia) and an increase in CSF protein concentration. However, GBS does not typically cause involuntary limb movements or cognitive defects. Moreover, patients with GBS usually have ascending muscle weakness (unlike this patient with 5/5 limb strength in all extremities) and CSF albuminocytologic dissociation (CSF cell counts higher than 50/mm3 make GBS unlikely).

C) INCORRECT:

Antibodies targeting acetylcholine receptors cause myasthenia gravis (MG), which would present with symptoms such as muscle weakness, diplopia, and/or ptosis. MG does not cause cognitive or speech defects. Moreover, paraneoplastic MG is typically associated with thymoma. A different paraneoplastic disorder is more likely in this patient with normal limb strength, cognitive defects, and an adnexal mass.
Image Description:

Blockade of ACh receptors (Left): ACh antibodies bind to postsynaptic ACh receptors and inhibit muscle activation.

Receptor internalization/degradation (middle): Binding of ACh antibody results in accelerated receptor degradation. The receptor is internalized and degraded by the muscle cell.

Complement activation (right): Binding of ACh autoantibodies results in complement activation and membrane attack complex formation, leading to the destruction of the neuromuscular junction and muscle cell lysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Autoantibodies against neuronal Hu antigens can cause paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis, as seen here. However, anti-Hu encephalitis is typically a paraneoplastic manifestation of small cell lung cancer. A different diagnosis is more likely in this patient with an adnexal mass.

E) CORRECT:

NMDA glutamate receptors are targeted by antibodies in anti-NMDA encephalitis, which is a type of PEM that is typically associated with ovarian teratoma. Patients with PEM can have a prodrome of fever, headache, and fatigue lasting weeks to months before the onset of features of CNS damage. CSF analysis of patients with PEM can show lymphocytic pleocytosis with increased protein concentration. Another cause of PEM is autoantibodies against neuronal Hu antigens (anti-Hu encephalitis), which typically occur in patients with small cell lung cancer.
questions.hint: This patient with an adnexal mass has features of paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis (PEM), such as cognitive defects, personality changes, speech impairment, involuntary limb movements, and autonomic instability (tachycardia, hypotension).

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed tonic-clonic seizure. His wife says he has had a persistent dry cough for 6 months. During this time period, he has also had fatigue and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. The patient has no history of serious illness and does not take any medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He is confused and oriented only to person. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 119 mEq/L and glucose concentration of 102 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows an irregular, poorly demarcated mass at the right hilum. Microscopic examination of this mass is most likely to confirm which of the following diagnoses?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although squamous cell lung carcinoma is the most common lung cancer in smokers and can also manifest with a central mass, it is not typically associated with SIADH. Instead, it causes hypercalcemia due to the release of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP).
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) CORRECT:

Microscopic examination of this hilar density is most likely to reveal a small cell lung carcinoma. SIADH is one of the common paraneoplastic syndromes associated with SCLC; others include Cushing syndrome and Lambert-Eaton syndrome.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

There are sheets of small cells with hyperchromic, pleomorphic nuclei, and minimal cytoplasm. Mitotic figures are present. The stroma appears delicate and scant compared to the sheets of abnormal cells.

These findings are consistent with small cell lung carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Large cell lung carcinoma is unlikely since it typically has peripheral localization and is not associated with SIADH. In some cases, it may cause paraneoplastic secretion of G-CSF or gynecomastia due to secretion of the beta subunit of β-HCG.

D) INCORRECT:

A bronchial carcinoid tumor is unlikely in this patient because it is not associated with SIADH. Instead, it can cause carcinoid syndrome (due to ectopic serotonin secretion).

E) INCORRECT:

While lung adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer overall, it is associated with hypercoagulability, thrombophlebitis migrans, and nonbacterial verrucous endocarditis rather than SIADH. Additionally, lung adenocarcinoma typically has peripheral localization on imaging, unlike this patient's findings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Several confluent tubular glands lined by atypical epithelium (examples indicated by green outline) and surrounded by desmoplastic hypercellular stroma are visible. There is nuclear stratification (nuclei located at different heights within the epithelium rather than basally only), nuclear hyperchromasia (darker stained nuclei), and pleomorphism (different sizes of cells and nuclei).

These are typical findings in acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung.
questions.hint: Hyponatremia in a smoker with weight loss and persistent cough suggests a paraneoplastic syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and repeated falls. Neurologic examination shows past-pointing on a finger-nose test. She has a broad-based gait. Ophthalmologic exam shows rhythmic leftward movement of the globes. A serum antibody assay is positive for anti-Yo antibodies directed at proteins expressed by Purkinje cells. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian teratomas can present with anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis, which is associated with antibodies to the GluN1 (NR1) subunit of the NMDA receptor, not the anti-Yo antibodies detected here. In addition, this patient is 61 years and ovarian teratomas primarily occur in women between 10 and 30 years of age. Ovarian carcinomas, on the other hand, are a cause of anti-Yo antibody-associated PCD.

B) INCORRECT:

Neuroblastomas are associated with opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome. While this disorder is thought to be immune-mediated, there is currently no known association with an antibody. This patient has ataxia and jerking eye movements but she does not have myoclonus. In addition, this patient is 61 years and neuroblastomas occur almost exclusively in children.

C) CORRECT:

Breast cancer is the most common cause of anti-Yo antibody-associated paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (PCD) in women. PCD is a rare syndrome that usually occurs as the first manifestation of the malignancy and presents with symptoms of cerebellar dysfunction (e.g., dizziness, ataxia, nystagmus, dysmetria). Other causes of anti-Yo antibody-associated PCD are malignant tumors of the ovary, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.

D) INCORRECT:

Thymomas are associated with antibodies against the postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction (AChR-Ab), not anti-Yo antibodies. AChR-Abs are involved in the pathogenesis of myasthenia gravis, not PCD.

E) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphomas can cause PCD, but they are associated with anti-Tr antibodies, not anti-Yo antibodies.
questions.hint: The anti-Yo antibody, or Purkinje cell cytoplasmic antibody type 1, is an autoantibody that causes paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (PCD). These antibodies are associated with a tumor that may be caused by amplification or overexpression of the gene that encodes human epidermal growth factor receptor 2.

questions.text: An investigator is analyzing the serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels of 100 patients. A scatter plot of the findings is shown. Which of the following is a possible explanation for the group marked with the letter E?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Group E represents participants with hypercalcemia despite low serum PTH. Non-PTH-mediated hypercalcemia most commonly occurs in malignancy (so-called hypercalcemia of malignancy) due to the paraneoplastic production of PTHrP (e.g., in squamous cell carcinomas of the lung, head, and neck; renal, bladder, breast, and ovarian cancer; lymphoma and leukemia). Other, less common causes of hypercalcemia of malignancy include osteolytic metastases (e.g., in multiple myeloma) and paraneoplastic production of calcitriol (e.g., in lymphoma).
Image Description:

When serum calcium levels decrease, parathyroid chief cells secrete parathyroid hormone (PTH), which regulates calcium levels via the following mechanisms:

1. PTH activates osteoclasts, which degrade bone, thereby releasing calcium and phosphate.
2. In the kidneys, PTH stimulates calcium reabsorption in the distal tubule and decreases phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubule.
3. PTH increases the expression of 1α-hydroxylase in the kidneys, an enzyme required to synthesize calcitriol. Calcitriol, in turn, stimulates renal and intestinal reabsorption of both calcium and phosphate. In contrast to PTH, calcitriol promotes the mineralization of bone using calcium and phosphate.

B) INCORRECT:

End-stage kidney disease (ESKD) causes decreased biosynthesis of active vitamin D, which leads to decreased calcium reabsorption in the intestines and distal convoluted tubule, resulting in hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia then triggers PTH secretion, causing elevated serum PTH levels (i.e., secondary hyperparathyroidism) as depicted in Group A.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with celiac disease often have vitamin D deficiency, which results in decreased intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphate. The resulting hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia stimulate the parathyroid glands to secrete PTH (i.e., secondary hyperparathyroidism). Therefore, patients with celiac disease would be expected to have hypocalcemia and elevated PTH levels, as depicted in Group C.
Image Description:

Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) is mainly synthesized in the body, but it can also be taken up with food and supplements.

Endogenous vitamin D synthesis involves a series of steps:
1. provitamin D3 (7-dehydrocholesterol) is synthesized from cholesterol in the liver and the skin.
2. provitamin D3 is converted in the skin with the help of UV radiation to vitamin D3.
3. Vitamin D3 is hydroxylated to calcidiol (25-hydroxycholecalciferol) in the liver (by the enzyme 25-hydroxylase)
4. Vitamin D3 is hydroxylated to calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3, which is biologically active) in the kidneys (by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase). Parathyroid hormone and cAMP promote this last step by stimulating 1α-hydroxylase. Calcium, phosphate, and FGF-23 inhibit 1α-hydroxylase.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroidectomy may result in transient or permanent hypoparathyroidism due to ischemic damage or accidental removal of the parathyroid glands. Hypoparathyroidism results in hypocalcemia and low serum PTH levels, as depicted in Group D.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with multiple endocrine neoplasia (primarily MEN 1 and to a lesser extent MEN 2A) often have primary hyperparathyroidism as one of the manifestations of their condition. Although these individuals have hypercalcemia, they also have elevated serum PTH, corresponding to Group B on the scatter plot.
questions.hint: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is secreted in response to decreased serum ionized calcium, increased serum phosphate, or decreased serum vitamin D. It acts to increase calcium and phosphate reabsorption from the bones, increase calcium and decrease phosphate reabsorption in the kidneys, and increase vitamin D production.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department for the evaluation of worsening fatigue, urinary frequency, and constipation over the past 5 days. He was recently diagnosed with metastatic bladder cancer and is currently awaiting treatment. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and diffuse abdominal tenderness. An ECG shows a shortened QT interval. Which of the following sets of serum findings is most likely in this patient?



Calcium
Phosphorus
Parathyroid hormone
1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D



A
↓
↑
↑
↓


B
↑
↑
↓
↑


C
↑
↑
↑
↓


D
↑
↓
↑
↑


E
↑
↓
↓
↓
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These laboratory values can be seen in pseudohypoparathyroidism (PHP), which is caused by renal tubular resistance to PTH. End-organ resistance to PTH leads to decreased phosphate excretion and calcium absorption by the kidneys, as well as impaired ability to produce 1-alpha-hydroxylase in the proximal tubules. Therefore, patients with PHP classically present with hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, increased PTH levels, and decreased 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels. In addition, PHP most commonly manifests during childhood with features of Albright hereditary osteodystrophy (e.g., short stature, round face, obesity, and shortened fourth and fifth metacarpals).

B) INCORRECT:

These laboratory values can be seen in hypervitaminosis D secondary to excess vitamin D intake or excess production of vitamin D, as seen in granulomatous diseases (e.g., sarcoidosis) or lymphomas. Hypervitaminosis D increases calcium and phosphorus absorption and suppresses PTH secretion. Thus, acute vitamin D intoxication can manifest with symptoms of hypercalcemia, which are seen here. In this patient, however, there is no report of excess vitamin D intake and there are no clinical features of granulomatous disease or lymphoma.

C) INCORRECT:

These laboratory values are seen in tertiary hyperparathyroidism (tHPT), which is most commonly caused by chronic kidney disease (CKD). In individuals with CKD, insufficient production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D causes hypocalcemia, which can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism (sHPT). Persistent sHPT leads to the development of functionally autonomous parathyroid glands that continually release PTH (i.e., tHPT), inducing increased bone resorption and hypercalcemia. Patients with tHPT commonly have decreased phosphate excretion due to impaired renal function. Although this patient presents with symptoms of hypercalcemia, he does not have a history of CKD.

D) INCORRECT:

These laboratory values are seen in primary hyperparathyroidism (pHPT), which is most commonly caused by parathyroid adenoma. In pHPT, high levels of PTH increase serum calcium levels by increasing bone turnover and renal calcium reabsorption. Increased PTH levels also cause hypophosphatemia by preventing renal phosphate reabsorption. Moreover, PTH induces renal hydroxylation of 25-dihydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. pHPT is usually asymptomatic but may manifest with clinical features of hypercalcemia, which is seen here. This patient, however, has a recent history of bladder cancer rather than parathyroid gland adenoma or hyperplasia of the parathyroid glands.

E) CORRECT:

These laboratory values are seen in humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy, which is caused by PTHrP secretion from solid tumors (most commonly renal cancer, bladder cancer, ovarian cancer, or squamous cell cancers of the head, neck, or lung). PTHrP can activate PTH receptors and increase bone resorption, renal calcium absorption and phosphate excretion, leading to severe hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia. Hypercalcemia further suppresses the secretion of PTH, causing decreased serum PTH levels. Unlike PTH, PTHrP does not stimulate the hydroxylation of 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D.
Image Description:

When serum calcium levels decrease, parathyroid chief cells secrete parathyroid hormone (PTH), which regulates calcium levels via the following mechanisms:

1. PTH activates osteoclasts, which degrade bone, thereby releasing calcium and phosphate.
2. In the kidneys, PTH stimulates calcium reabsorption in the distal tubule and decreases phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubule.
3. PTH increases the expression of 1α-hydroxylase in the kidneys, an enzyme required to synthesize calcitriol. Calcitriol, in turn, stimulates renal and intestinal reabsorption of both calcium and phosphate. In contrast to PTH, calcitriol promotes the mineralization of bone using calcium and phosphate.
questions.hint: In an individual with advanced bladder cancer, the presence of fatigue, urinary frequency, constipation, dry mucous membranes, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and shortened QT interval indicate hypercalcemia of malignancy, which is likely due to the production of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP).

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of worsening cough and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Physical examination shows wheezing over the right lung fields. Laboratory studies show a serum calcium concentration of 12.5 mg/dL. X-rays of the chest are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lobar pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus or by anaerobes (due to aspiration) can result in a cavitary lesion due to a lung abscess. However, pneumonia is an acute illness that is associated with a fever and a productive cough, unlike this patient who has had a cough for the past 4 months. Also, pneumonia can cause hyponatremia due to SIADH but it does not cause hypercalcemia.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lung abscess

A large thick-walled (green overlay) cavity projecting over the perihilar region of the right lung contains an air-fluid level (indicated by red line).

The differential for this appearance includes abscess (bacterial, mycobacterial, fungal), cavitary noninfectious granuloma, and cavitary malignant lesion.

B) INCORRECT:

A cough and weight loss in an older patient with a long history of smoking raise suspicion for lung cancer. Small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) is strongly associated with smoking; however, it typically manifests in the proximal bronchi as a central nodule and does not usually form cavitary lesions. Furthermore, SCLC can cause several paraneoplastic syndromes such as Cushing syndrome, SIADH, Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, and paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis but it does not cause hypercalcemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis can cause a cough, weight loss, and a cavitary lesion on x-ray. Severe pulmonary tuberculosis can also result in hypercalcemia. However, cavitary tuberculous lesions typically form in the superior lobes and are often associated with additional symptoms such as fever and night sweats. In this patient with a 35 pack year smoking history and no history of immunocompromise or tuberculosis exposure, a different diagnosis is much more likely.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

D) INCORRECT:

The constellation of pulmonary symptoms, constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss), and hypercalcemia raises suspicion for sarcoidosis. However, a chest x-ray in a patient with sarcoidosis would show coarse reticular opacities and/or bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. The presence of a solitary cavitary lesion suggests a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient with sarcoidosis

The pulmonary hila (green overlay) are enlarged and lobulated. Additionally, the right superior mediastinum (red overlay) is widened and dense. A normal thin right paratracheal stripe is not seen.

Relatively symmetric bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph node enlargement on a chest radiograph in sarcoidosis is termed the “1-2-3 sign” or “Garland triad.” Examples of other causes of hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy include lymphoma, metastatic disease, granulomatous infections, and inorganic dust disease.

E) CORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung is the most common type of lung cancer that develops in smokers and can cause centrally located cavitary lesions as seen in this case. Although paraneoplastic syndromes are generally more common in patients with small cell lung cancer, certain paraneoplastic syndromes such as humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (HHM) primarily arise in association with SCC. HHM is caused by the production of parathyroid hormone-related protein, which stimulates PTH receptors and thereby increases bone resorption, renal calcium reabsorption, and phosphate excretion, which results in hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma can manifest with weight loss and hypercalcemia. However, this condition would not cause the patient's pulmonary symptoms or x-ray findings. Instead, patients typically present with back pain and fatigue.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myeloma

Multiple punched-out lytic lesions (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible. This appearance is termed “raindrop sign” from the resemblance of these lesions to raindrops splashing upon hitting a surface.

An expanded differential of lucent skull lesions includes osteoporosis of aging, hyperparathyroidism, metastatic disease, anemias (e.g., sickle cell and thalassemia), and the lytic phase of Paget disease.
questions.hint: The x-rays show a heterogeneous, irregularly demarcated lesion with a central cavity and air-fluid level in the right middle lobe. Which respiratory pathology can also cause hypercalcemia?

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in his apartment. He has noticed that it is easier for him to climb the stairs after he has exercised. He has also had a 4.6-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Muscle strength in the proximal lower extremity is initially 3/5 but increases to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping. His Achilles reflex is 1+. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) manifests with muscle weakness and may rarely be associated with dysautonomia. However, muscle weakness typically is asymmetric and would not improve with exercise, but show a progressive course. Since both upper and lower motor neurons are affected in ALS, additional symptoms such as hyperreflexia, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness would be expected.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

B) INCORRECT:

Polymyalgia rheumatica manifests with proximal myopathy, but its main symptoms are myalgia and muscle stiffness rather than weakness. Systemic symptoms, such as weight loss, may be seen in polymyalgia rheumatica, but autonomic dysfunction and hyporeflexia would not be expected. Polymyalgia rheumatica is not associated with lung cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) may cause lower limb muscle weakness. However, symptoms typically worsen throughout the day and with exercise as opposed to this patient's improvement of symptoms upon repetitive stimulation. MG classically manifests with weakness of the extraocular muscles causing ptosis and/or diplopia, whereas deep tendon reflexes and autonomic functions are unaffected. Moreover, MG is not associated with lung cancer, but with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases.

D) INCORRECT:

Dermatomyositis manifests with proximal muscle weakness. However, symptoms are typically progressive and would not improve with exercise. Although dermatomyositis is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer, cutaneous manifestations such as Gottron papules and a heliotrope rash would also be expected. Moreover, dermatomyositis is not associated with hyporeflexia and autonomic dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism may cause proximal muscle weakness and hyporeflexia. However, it would usually be associated with other symptoms such as weight gain, fatigue, cold intolerance, and dry skin. Weight loss as seen in this patient would be unusual. Hypothyroidism is not associated with lung cancer.

F) CORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which is associated with small-cell lung cancer in two-thirds of cases, is caused by circulating autoantibodies that block presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels (anti-VGCC antibodies) at the neuromuscular junction. This blockage impairs acetylcholine (ACh) release, which leads to reduced or absent deep tendon reflexes and proximal muscle weakness; the latter improves during exercise as repetitive nerve stimulation increases the amount of ACh in the synaptic cleft. Patients with LEMS may also develop symptoms of autonomic dysfunction such as a dry mouth, constipation, or impotence.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody
questions.hint: This patient's combination of smoking history, chronic cough, and weight loss is concerning for lung malignancy. Proximal muscle weakness that improves on repeated stimulation combined with hyporeflexia is suggestive of a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of upper extremity weakness and fatigue for the past 4 months. She has had difficulty combing her hair and lifting objects. She has also had difficulty rising from her bed in the mornings for 2 months. Over the past month, she started using over-the-counter mouth rinses for dry mouth. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Examination shows decreased deep tendon reflexes. Repetitive muscle tapping shows increased reflex activity. There are no fasciculations or muscle atrophy. A low-dose CT scan of the chest shows a 3-cm mass with heterogeneous calcifications in the center of the right lung. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The CNS is one of the most common locations for lung cancer metastasis, which can present with focal neurological deficits. Patients with brain metastasis may exhibit muscle weakness, as seen here. However, upper motor neuron symptoms (e.g., hyperreflexia, spasticity) would also be expected, rather than the decreased deep tendon reflexes observed in this patient. In addition, brain metastasis commonly presents with headaches, cognitive deficits, and seizures, none of which are present here. Moreover, her autonomic symptom (dry mouth) and the increased reflex activity noted after repeated stimulation are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory myopathies (IM), such as polymyositis and dermatomyositis, typically manifest with proximal muscle weakness, as seen in this patient. However, her autonomic symptom (dry mouth) and the decreased deep tendon reflexes with improvement after repeated stimulation are inconsistent with IM. Although a strong association exists between dermatomyositis and malignancy, this patient lacks the typical cutaneous manifestations of this disease (i.e., Gottron papules, heliotrope rash), which excludes dermatomyositis as the underlying mechanism responsible for her presentation.

C) CORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is a paraneoplastic autoimmune disease, most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer. In LEMS, antibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels impair acetylcholine (ACh) release in the neuromuscular junction. This leads to proximal muscle weakness, autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth, constipation), and decreased deep tendon reflexes, as seen in this patient. A unique feature of LEMS is an improvement in strength and reflex activity with repeated use/stimulation. Since postsynaptic ACh receptors remain intact in LEMS, once enough ACh has built up in the postsynaptic cleft from repeated stimulation, muscle contraction can return.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

D) INCORRECT:

Hereditary causes of muscle weakness include muscular dystrophies (e.g., Duchenne muscular dystrophy), hereditary motor sensory neuropathies (HMSN) (e.g., Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease), and congenital myopathies. Although decreased deep tendon reflexes, as seen here, may be found in all of these conditions, increased reflex activity after repeated stimulation would not be present. Moreover, further symptoms such as muscle atrophy and, in the case of HMSN, sensory deficits would be expected. Finally, these hereditary conditions almost exclusively manifest in childhood or early adulthood.

E) INCORRECT:

Invasion of a lung carcinoma into the cervical sympathetic chain can lead to Pancoast syndrome, presenting with upper extremity weakness and loss of deep tendon reflexes, as seen in this patient. However, muscle weakness in Pancoast syndrome is typically unilateral. In addition, further symptoms caused by the compression or infiltration of local structures by the tumor would be expected (e.g., shoulder pain, muscle atrophy, sensory deficits, Horner syndrome, hoarseness, and superior vena cava syndrome). An increase in reflex activity noted after repeated stimulation is inconsistent with this diagnosis. Moreover, the patient's CT revealed a mass in the center of the right lung, whereas Pancoast tumors are always located in the superior sulcus.

F) INCORRECT:

Some viral infections that affect the anterior horn cells can cause muscle weakness, resulting in flaccid paralysis or invasion of the muscle itself (i.e., myositis). Viruses that cause flaccid paralysis include poliovirus, nonpolio enteroviruses, and West Nile virus, all of which are extremely unlikely in a patient without a travel history to endemic areas. Moreover, further symptoms such as muscle fasciculations, atrophy, and signs of infection (e.g., fever, malaise, headache) would be expected. Viral myositis is commonly caused by influenza viruses and enteroviruses; patients typically present with fever, myalgia, and a history of an upper respiratory tract infection, none of which are seen in this patient. Additionally, her slowly progressive symptoms, autonomic symptom (dry mouth), and the increased reflex activity noted after repeated stimulation are inconsistent with an infectious cause.
questions.hint: A CT scan showing a 3-cm pulmonary mass with irregular calcifications in a patient with a 40 pack-year history of cigarette smoking is suspicious for lung malignancy.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman reports to the emergency department with a 3-month history of increasing difficulty getting out of chairs, climbing stairs, and managing daily activities. She can no longer get out of bed herself and reports weakness, easy bruising, worsening of her chronic cough, and weight loss of 9.1 kg.
Her medical history is notable only for osteoarthritis of the knee, for which she takes ibuprofen as needed, and mild contact dermatitis controlled with the use of over-the-counter hydrocortisone lotion. She reports no use of diuretics. She is retired, has smoked 10 cigarettes per day for the past 50 years, and drinks one to two alcoholic drinks per week.
On physical examination, her blood pressure is 163/88 mm Hg. She is thin, has marked proximal muscle weakness, and has several bruises on her forearms and shins.
Laboratory evaluation reveals the following levels:



Patient value
Reference range



Potassium (mEq/liter)
2.2
3.5–5.0


Sodium (mEq/liter)
143
136–145



Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
34
21–30


Chloride (mEq/liter)
98
98–106



Fasting glucose (mg/dL)
193
70–100


What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid-remediable aldosteronism is a genetic disease and would not have its onset at an older age.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone cream is not very potent, so its use is unlikely to be associated with the rapidly progressive features of Cushing syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

An ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma or a cortisol-producing adrenocortical adenoma can cause Cushing syndrome, but they are usually slower to progress than ectopic ACTH production and more likely to be associated with weight gain rather than weight loss. In these two conditions, signs and symptoms of cortisol excess (e.g., weight gain, centripetal adiposity, and proximal myopathy) dominate the clinical presentation. Hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis are not features of mild or moderate hypercortisolism.

D) INCORRECT:

An ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma or a cortisol-producing adrenocortical adenoma can cause Cushing syndrome, but they are usually slower to progress than ectopic ACTH production and more likely to be associated with weight gain rather than weight loss. In these two conditions, signs and symptoms of cortisol excess (e.g., weight gain, centripetal adiposity, and proximal myopathy) dominate the clinical presentation. Hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis are not features of mild or moderate hypercortisolism.

E) CORRECT:

Ectopic production of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is seen in many tumors, particularly small-cell lung carcinomas, and occurs in patients with rapidly progressive Cushing syndrome. There may be modest physical findings of cortisol excess, but metabolic abnormalities (e.g., hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and hyperglycemia) dominate the clinical presentation because of the severe and usually sudden onset of hypercortisolism. There are multiple potential causes of the patient’s hypokalemia and hyperglycemia. However, in cases where symptoms are rapidly progressive and associated with weight loss and marked metabolic abnormalities, ectopic ACTH production is the most likely diagnosis. The weight loss is caused by the underlying cancer.

Key learning point: New-onset metabolic abnormalities associated with Cushing syndrome (e.g., hypokalemia or hyperglycemia) with only modest findings of cortisol excess on physical examination is most consistent with ectopic production of adrenocorticotropic hormone.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman presents with nausea, vomiting, and epigastric pain. She reports nonspecific abdominal discomfort, dark stools and dark urine, and a 9.1-kg weight loss during the past 3 months. Physical examination reveals notable skin lesions (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The velvety, hyperpigmented patches present in the skin folds of this patient are indicative of acanthosis nigricans, which is more commonly associated with gastric cancer than with other cancers.

B) CORRECT:

The velvety, hyperpigmented patches present in the skin folds of this patient are indicative of acanthosis nigricans, which is more commonly associated with gastric cancer than with other cancers. Other paraneoplastic entities that can be associated with gastric cancer include membranous nephropathy, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, hypercoagulable states (e.g., Trousseau syndrome), polyarteritis nodosa, and diffuse seborrheic keratoses (known as the Leser-Trélat sign).

Key learning point: The type of cancer with which acanthosis nigricans is most associated is gastric cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

The velvety, hyperpigmented patches present in the skin folds of this patient are indicative of acanthosis nigricans, which is more commonly associated with gastric cancer than with other cancers.

D) INCORRECT:

The velvety, hyperpigmented patches present in the skin folds of this patient are indicative of acanthosis nigricans, which is more commonly associated with gastric cancer than with other cancers.

E) INCORRECT:

The velvety, hyperpigmented patches present in the skin folds of this patient are indicative of acanthosis nigricans, which is more commonly associated with gastric cancer than with other cancers.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man with recently diagnosed relapsed stage IV squamous-cell carcinoma of the lung presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of nausea, vomiting, pain in the left upper quadrant, muscle weakness, and delirium. His oral intake is decreased.
On initial examination, his heart rate is 110 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg, and his respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 100% while he is breathing ambient air. His weight is 88 kg. He has mild-to-moderate tenderness to palpation in the left upper quadrant and poor skin turgor. He is oriented only to his name and place.
He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Laboratory findings are as follows:
